abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Project
            outcome is satisfactory, sustainability is likely,
            institutional development impact is substantial, Bank
            performance is satisfactory, and borrower performance is
            satisfactory. A number of valuable lessons were learned from
            implementing this project, and have been incorporated in the
            follow-on project, UBSIP2, as appropriate. They include the
            following:  1) Procurement was complex because of (1) IDA
            prior review of all aspects of procurement from designs, bid
            documents, and contract awards; (2) a large number of small
            packages; and (3) the enactment and implementation of a new
            procurement law in Mongolia from 2001, which introduced high
            level interdepartmental committees for procurement, and
            delayed contract awards significantly. These issues have
            been addressed in UBSIP2 through better packaging and
            establishment of prior review thresholds. In addition,
            following the IDA Country Procurement Assessment Report of
            2003, Mongolia's procurement law is being revised with
            a view to overcoming the major issues identified.  2)
            Consultant support for design review, construction
            supervision, and project management: During implementation
            the SAR assumption that consultant support for these
            activities would only be required during the first two years
            was much too optimistic. In practice, consultant support
            became essential until the extended project closing date of
            December 2003. UBSIP2 will include consultant support
            throughout that project. In addition, in order to improve
            construction supervision, UBSIP2 will involve the
            Ulaanbaatar Water and Sewerage Company (USAG) through a
            Project Implementation Unit, with adequate staff. 3)
            Designs:  Chief issues are the extent of protection required
            against freezing and the need to standardize designs of
            pumping stations, bath houses, and water kiosks. These
            matters have been addressed in UBSIP2. 4) While
            institutional development of USAG was very successful
            overall, a number of second generation issues remain. These
            include the development of policies for metering and house
            connections, an appropriate role for the private sector,
            further improvements to maintenance, development and
            implementation of a communication strategy, and on-going
            upgrading of staff skills. Again, these are being addressed
            under UBSIP2. 5) Financial sustainability of USAG -The
            project did not succeed in its ambitious objective of making
            USAG commercially viable from an early stage because of a
            variety of factors, including the need for a phased
            progression to commercial operation and the lack of
            Government (also, local government) commitment to
            USAG's financial objectives. Under UBSIP2 periodic
            tariff increases required for financial viability will be a
            disbursement condition for implement ting the physical
            investment program. 6) Medium-term water and sanitation
            strategy - This is needed to determine the feasibility of
            expanding the water supply network to germ areas, the
            strategy for sanitation in germ areas, the institutional
            framework for the water sector, and the prospects for
            involving the private sector in the overall management of
            USAG. IDA will assist Government in obtaining grant
            technical assistance for this work.

abstracts.cdata!:
The general objectives of the
            Ulaanbaatar Services Improvement Project are to assist the
            Government to: (i) address the inequity of services between
            ger and formal housing areas, thereby improving the quality
            of life of the low-income population; (ii) restore levels
            and quality of water supply services in the Municipality and
            make that supply accessible to the ger areas; and (iii)
            develop more efficient and autonomous, performance-oriented
            institutions, with a view to eventual privatization.
            Project's specific objectives are to: (i) improve the
            quality, quantity and reliability of water supply; (ii)
            substantially lower the unit cost of water supply to ger
            areas; (iii) improve ger area infrastructure; (iv) arrest
            the deterioration in, and improve the reliability and
            quality of, the city water distribution system; (v) reduce
            water wastage, the production of nonrevenue-producing water,
            and water production costs; (vi) replace the current
            norm-based water and sanitation billing system to one that
            is quantity-based; and (vii) develop the water and
            sanitation company of Ulaanbaatar's (USAG's)
            capabilities for financial and operational management and
            convert it into a self-financing commercially-oriented
            public utility.  The project will include: 1) physical
            investments such as strengthening of water supply
            distribution network, concrete reservoirs construction,
            insulated pipelines, water leakage and wastage reduction
            program, equipment and tools for maintenance and meter
            repair workshops, sewer observation and cleaning equipment,
            and Ger Area Infrastructure Upgrading Program; and 2)
            institutional component consisting of technical assistance
            in project management, institutional strengthening of USAG,
            studies reviewing the long-term development and planning of
            ger areas and definition of appropriate levels of public
            services, and development of and training in a computerized
            USAG billing and collection system for metered supplies.

repnme.cdata!:
Mongolia - Urban Services Rehabilitation
            Project Phase 2

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental impact assessment for
            the Mongolia Urban Services Rehabilitation Project Phase 2
            concludes that a new sanitary engineered landfill located at
            Moringiin Davaa is the most environmentally sustainable
            option for solid waste disposal for the Municipality of
            Ulaanbaatar. The facility would replace three existing
            landfill operations. Potential environmental impacts
            include: a) soil erosion /silt runoff - mitigated by
            restoration of soil, placement of hay bales, and erection of
            concrete rock works; b) air pollution from landfill gas -
            remaining within acceptable levels; c) increased traffic
            generation - only to occur during working hours; d) noise -
            this will increase during construction; e) visual amenity -
            minimal as the site would be buried f) water quality -
            negligible impact; g) dust and odor - mitigated by daily
            monitoring, watering the area, and ensuring that latrine
            operation is sanitary; and h) flora and fauna - impacts will
            be insignificant.

Mongolia - Urban Services Rehabilitation
